content: The maritime industry, including commercial vessels like tankers, bulk carriers, and passenger ships, is regulated by international protocols and U.S. laws to prevent pollution and protect marine resources. Enforcement and jurisdiction issues exist, with a focus on the cruise industry due to its visibility and environmental impact concerns. The cruise industry, representing a small fraction of the global shipping fleet, is a significant contributor to the U.S. economy, providing $40 billion in benefits in 2009 and over 357,000 jobs. With an average annual growth rate of 7.4% in the number of passengers since 1990, cruises hosted 14.3 million passengers in 2010. The fleet consists of more than 230 ships, mostly foreign-flagged, with Liberia and Panama being popular flag countries. The cruise industry's fleet comprises over 230 ships, mostly foreign-flagged with Liberia and Panama being popular choices. Six companies own nearly 95% of passenger ships in U.S. waters. New ships are added each year, larger and more luxurious, with an average size increase of 90 feet every five years. The industry focuses on demonstrating safety and health for passengers and visited communities. Cruise ships, often compared to "floating cities," generate large amounts of sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, solid waste, and oily bilge water during voyages. Improper disposal of these wastes can pose risks to human health and the environment. Concerns have been raised about the adequacy of laws for managing cruise ship waste, with weak enforcement noted. A 2000 GAO report highlighted issues with cruise ships' compliance with environmental laws, revealing 87 confirmed illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters between 1993 and 1998. Most cases involved oil or oil-based products, with some intentional and accidental discharges. These cruise ship cases accounted for 4% of all illegal discharge cases by foreign-flag ships. The 2000 GAO report revealed that 87 confirmed illegal discharge cases by cruise ships in U.S. waters accounted for 4% of all cases by foreign-flag ships. Environmental advocates supported the legislation, while industry groups argued against targeting an industry with high environmental standards. Congress may need to address state-level regulations on cruise ship discharges and harmonize differences. The status of EPA's efforts to manage cruise ship wastes is also an issue for Congress. Congress authorized EPA to issue standards for sewage and graywater discharges from large cruise ships in Alaska in 2000. EPA has been collecting information and assessing the need for additional standards but has not proposed any rules yet. In December 2008, EPA released a Cruise Ship Discharge Assessment Report that examines five cruise ship waste streams and discusses current federal actions to address them. The report discusses possible options to address cruise ship discharges, highlighting the need for harmonizing U.S. laws and updating regulations to reflect improved technology. EPA has not determined the necessity or feasibility of these options. The U.S. Commission on Ocean Policy emphasized the importance of research to understand cruise ship waste generation, impacts of discharges, and potential control technologies. The Coast Guard is responsible for enforcing federal programs on cruise ship pollution, including monitoring pollution prevention equipment and verifying proper waste disposal. The EPA has identified options for improving enforcement and compliance on cruise ship pollution, including enhancing monitoring, rewarding passengers for detecting illegal activities, allowing state personnel to inspect pollution control equipment, and charging a passenger fee for onboard marine engineers. The GAO found issues with the process for referring violations to other countries and recommended greater efforts by the Coast Guard to follow up on pollution cases occurring outside U.S. jurisdiction.
